answers.answer: I can't answer the non-diabetes questions. I do know that unstable thyroid levels will affect diabetes management so you do need to check and make sure your current dose of Synthroid is maintaining your thyroid at a good level.It is the nature of LADA/Type 1.5 to change over time as our pancreas produces less and less insulin and then we need to take more. Are you on a basal/bolus regiment (long acting insulin once or twice a day and short acting for meals.) Is your bolus matched to the carbs you actually consume? This is the most accurate way to manage diabetes with insulin. I suggest you see an endo to have your insulin doses reevaluated.

question: Was diagnosed with diabetes when I was 32 (almost ten years ago). There is no family history and I have never been overweight.  I admit that I've been stressed out often for prolonged periods of time.  Nevertheless, I have what is called type 1.5 diabetes.  I tried the pills, they did not work at all.  I started taking insulin and that seemed to work for a few years however, lately, my A1C has been gradually increasing no matter what I do.  It's now 8.6 at last blood test.  I also have hypothyroidism and take cynthroid.  I also have ovarian cysts and my DHEA always comes back very low 63 was my last reading on that.  My question is: is there a connection between my inability to absorb the insulin, my low DHEA levels and my ovarian cysts?  if I have the cysts removed and start taking DHEA do you think this would allow my body to absorb the insulin? I do exercise regularly. At the very least, please help me know what to ask my doctor to test further for.      Very tired of doing the same thing and getting nowhere.
title: Diabetes misdiagnosed
